article.paragraph: Use British EnglishOctober 2013Use dmy datesJuly 2013Infobox cheeseCheddar cheese [[File:Somerset-Cheddar.jpg|250px]] A block of Cheddar cheese England [[Somerset]] [[Cheddar, Somerset|Cheddar]] [[Cow]]s Frequently Hard 3–18 months depending on variety ''West Country Farmhouse Cheddar'' [[Protected Geographical Status|PDO]], ''Orkney Scottish Island Cheddar'' [[Protected Geographical Indication|PGI]] Cheddar cheeseis a relatively hard, off-white (or orange if spices such asannattoare added), sometimes "sharp" (i.e., acidic)-tasting, naturalcheese. Originating in the English village ofCheddar, SomersetCheddarinSomerset,Cite newsSeparating the curds from the wheyhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/5241544.stm[[BBC Radio 4]] Open Country21 August 2006SmaleWill7 August 2007cheeses of this style are produced beyond this region and in several countries around the world.

Cheddar is the most popular type of cheese in theUK, accounting for 51% of the country's 1.9 billion annual cheese market.Cite webThe Interview – Lactalis McLelland's 'Seriously': driving the Cheddar marketThe Grocery Traderhttp://www.grocerytrader.co.uk/News/October_2006/G_lactalis.html9 May 2007It is also the second-most-popular cheese in the US (behindmozzarella), with an average annual consumption ofconvert10lbkgonper capita.cite webhttp://www.idfa.org/news--views/media-kits/cheese/cheese-sales-and-trends/International Dairy Foods AssociationCheese Sales and Trends9 November 2010The United States producedconvert3233380000lbLT tinin 2010,cite webhttp://future.aae.wisc.edu/data/annual_values/by_area/154?tabCheddar Cheese Productionhttp://future.aae.wisc.edu/data/annual_values/by_area/154?tabUniversity of Wisconsin9 November 2010and the UKconvert258000LTtoffin 2008.cite newshttp://www.independent.co.uk/extras/big-question/the-big-question-if-cheddar-cheese-is-british-why-is-so-much-of-it-coming-from-abroad-1791185.html[[The Independent]]The Big Question: If Cheddar cheese is British, why is so much of it coming from abroad?AmolRajan22 September 20099 November 2010LondonThe term "Cheddar cheese" is widely used, but has noProtected Geographical StatusProtected Designation of Originwithin the European Union, although only Cheddar produced from local milk within four counties of south west England may use the name "West Country Farmhouse Cheddar".https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/271260/pfn-west-country-farmhouse-cheddar.pdfBrown, Steve; Blackmon, Kate; and Cousins, Paul.Operations management: policy, practice and performance improvement. Butterworth-Heinemann, 2001, pp. 265266.
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: The cheese originates from the village ofCheddar, SomersetCheddarinSomerset, south west England.Cheddar Gorgeon the edge of the village contains a number ofcaves, which provided the ideal humidity and steady temperature for maturing the cheese.Cheddar cheese traditionally had to be made withinconvert30mikmonofWells Cathedral.

Cheddar has been produced since at least the 12th century. Apipe rollspipe rollofHenry II of EnglandKing Henry IIfrom 1170 records the purchase ofconvert10240lbonat aFarthing (British coin)farthingper pound (totalingsd10.13s.4d, about 10.67 inDecimal Daydecimal currency).Cite webHistoryCheddar Gorge Cheese Companyhttp://www.cheddargorgecheeseco.co.uk/acatalog/about-cheddar-gorge.html1 August 2009Charles I of EnglandCharles I(16001649) also bought cheese from the village.Ancient RomeRomansmay have brought the recipe to Britain from theCantalregion of France.cite bookBarthélemyRolandSperat-CzarArnaudGuide du fromage: Choisir, reconnaître, goûter 1200 fromages du monde2003978-2-01-236867-589

Central to the modernisation and standardisation of Cheddar cheese was the 19th-century Somerset dairymanJoseph Harding.Cite webHistory of Cheddar CheeseIcons of Englandhttp://www.icons.org.uk/theicons/collection/cheddar-cheese/biography/history-of-cheddar-finished9 May 2007For his technical innovations, promotion of dairy hygiene, and volunteer dissemination of modern cheese-making techniques, he has been dubbed "the father of Cheddar cheese".Cite bookHeeleyAnneMary VidalJoseph Harding, Cheddar Cheese-Maker1996Friends of the Abbey BarnGlastonburyHarding introduced new equipment to the process of cheese-making, including his "revolving breaker" for curd cutting, saving much manual effort.Transactions of the Highland and Agricultural Society of Scotland,Highland and Agricultural Society of Scotland, 1866-7 volume 1, AberdeenChristabel Susan Lowry Orwin, Edith Holt Whetham, "History of British Agriculture, 18461914",Agriculture(1964), page 145The "Joseph Harding method" was the first modern system for Cheddar production based upon scientific principles. Harding stated that Cheddar cheese is "not made in the field, nor in thebyre, nor even in the cow, it is made in the dairy".Cite webhttp://www.gourmetbritain.com/encyclo_entry.php?itemEncyclopedia – Harding, JosephGourmet Britain23 June 2009His wife and he were behind the introduction of the cheese into Scotland and North America. His sons, Henry and William Harding, were responsible for introducing Cheddar cheese production to Australiacite bookFrom Artisans to "Factories": The Interpenetration of Craft and Industry in English Cheese-Making 1650–1950RichardBlundelAngelaTregearEnterprise and Society17 October 2006and facilitating the establishment of the cheese industry in New Zealand, respectively.

During theSecond World War, and for nearly a decade after, most milk in Britain was used for the making of one single kind of cheese nicknamed "government Cheddar" as part of war economies andRationing in the United Kingdomrationing.Cite webhttp://www.cooksinfo.com/government-cheddar-cheeseGovernment Cheddar CheesePractically Edible30 April 2011This almost resulted in wiping out all other cheese production in the country. Before theFirst World War, more than 3,500 cheese producers were in Britain; fewer than 100 remained after the Second World War.Cite newshttp://www.thestar.com/News/article/264784Cool Britannia rules the wheyPotterMich[[Toronto Star]]9 October 20074 January 2009

According to aUnited States Department of Agricultureresearcher, Cheddar cheese is the world's most popular variety of cheese, and the most studied type of cheese in scientific publications.cite newsTunickMichael H.23 February 2014The biggest cheese? Cheddarhttp://www.bostonglobe.com/ideas/2014/02/23/the-biggest-cheese-cheddar/FkfbWQnV45ZWaSDAnlMuXP/story.html[[The Boston Globe]]24 February 2014
article.heading: Process
article.paragraph: Thecurdsandwheyare separated usingrennet, an enzyme complex normally produced from the stomachs of newborn calves (invegetarianorkoshercheeses, bacterial, yeast or mould-derivedchymosinis used).Cite webhttp://www.vegsoc.org/info/cheese.html[[Vegetarian Society]]Information Sheet – Cheese & Rennet10 March 2008

"Cheddaring" refers to an additional step in the production of Cheddar cheese where, after heating, the curd is kneaded with salt, cut into cubes to drain the whey, and then stacked and turned.Cite newshttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/wine/main.jhtml?xmlThe Daily TelegraphSavvy shopper: Cheddar18 June 200510 March 2008LondonHarryMountStrong, extra-mature Cheddar, sometimes called vintage, needs to be matured for up to 15 months. The cheese is kept at a constant temperature, often requiring special facilities. As with other hard cheese varieties produced worldwide,cavesprovide an ideal environment for maturing cheese; still, today, some Cheddar cheese is matured in the caves atWookey Hole CavesWookey HoleandCheddar Gorge. Additionally, some versions of Cheddar cheese areSmoking (cooking)smoked.cite webhttp://books.google.com/books?idAmerican Cheesesgoogle.comKelly Jaggers,Moufflet: More Than 100 Gourmet Muffin Recipes That Rise to Any Occasion, p. 104.File:Cheddar cave cheese.jpgthumbrightCheddar cheese maturing in the caves atCheddar Gorge
article.heading: Character
article.paragraph: File:MidSomerset Show 170803.jpgleftthumbCheddar cheeses on display at the Mid Somerset ShowThe ideal quality of the original Somerset Cheddar was described by Joseph Harding in 1864 as "close and firm in texture, yet mellow in character or quality; it is rich with a tendency to melt in the mouth, the flavour full and fine, approaching to that of a hazelnut".Transactions of the New-York State Agricultural Society for the Year 1864, page 232, volume 14 1865, Albany

Cheddar made in the classical way tends to have a sharp, pungent flavour, often slightly earthy. Its texture is firm, with farmhouse traditional Cheddar being slightly crumbly; it should also, if mature, contain largecheese crystalsconsisting ofcalcium lactate  often precipitated when matured for times longer than six months.Cite thesisPhadungathChanokphatThe Efficacy of Sodium Gluconate as a Calcium Lactate Crystal Inhibitor in Cheddar Cheesehttp://purl.umn.edu/1162782011University of Minnesota12 October 2013

Cheddar can be a deep to pale yellow (off-white) colour, or a yellow-orange colour when certain plant extracts are added. One commonly used spice isannatto, extracted from seeds of the tropicalAchioteachiote tree. Annatto is added to give Cheddar a sweet, nutty flavour. The largest producer of Cheddar cheese in the United States,Kraft FoodsKraft, uses a combination of annatto and oleoresin paprika, an extract of the lipophilic (oily) portion ofpaprika.cite bookFeldmanDavidWhen Do Fish Sleep? And Other Imponderables of Everyday Life1989Harper & Row, Publishers, Inc.0-06-016161-215

Cheddar cheese was sometimes (and still can be found) packaged in black wax, but was more commonly packaged in larded cloth, which was impermeable to contaminants, but still allowed the cheese to "breathe".

TheSlow FoodSlow Food Movementhas created a CheddarPresidium,Cite webBlulab sashttp://www.slowfoodfoundation.org/eng/presidi/dettaglio.lasso?codLa Fondazione – slow food per la biodiversità – ONLUSSlowfoodfoundation.org23 June 2009claiming that only three cheeses should be called "original Cheddar". Their specifications, which go further than the "West Country Farmhouse Cheddar"Protected Designation of OriginPDO, require that Cheddar cheese be made in Somerset and with traditional methods, such as using raw milk, traditional animalrennet, and a cloth wrapping.Cite webPresidia Artisan Somerset CheddarThe Slow Food Foundationhttp://www.slowfoodfoundation.com/eng/presidi/dettaglio.lasso?cod9 May 2007
article.heading: International production
article.paragraph: The Cheddar cheese name is used internationally; its name does not have a PDO, but the use of the name "West Country Farmhouse Cheddar" does. As well as the United Kingdom, countries making Cheddar cheese presently include Australia, Argentina, Belgium, Canada, Ireland, the Netherlands, New Zealand, South Africa, Sweden, and the United States. Cheddars can be industrial orartisan cheeses. The flavour, colour, and quality of industrial cheese varies significantly, and food packaging will usually indicate a strength, such as mild, medium, strong, tasty, sharp, extra sharp, mature, old, or vintage; this may indicate the maturation period, or food additives used to enhance the flavour. Artisan varieties develop strong and diverse flavours over time.
article.heading: Australia
article.paragraph: As of 2013, Cheddar accounts for over 55% of the Australian cheese market, with average annual consumption aroundconvert7.5kgonper person.http://www.dairyaustralia.com.au/~/media/Documents/Stats%20and%20markets/In%20Focus/Australian%20Dairy%20Industry%20In%20Focus%202013.pdfCheddar is so ubiquitous that the name is rarely used: instead, Cheddar is sold by strength alone as e.g. "mild", "tasty" or "sharp".cite webhttp://www.begacheese.com.au/products/natural/Natural
article.heading: Canada
article.paragraph: Following a wheat midge outbreak in Canada in the mid-19th century, farmers inOntariobegan to convert todairy farmingin large numbers, and Cheddar cheese became their main exportable product, even being exported to England. By the turn of the 20th century, 1,242 Cheddar factories were in Ontario, and Cheddar had become Canadas second-largest export after timber.cite webhttp://thewalrus.ca/manufacturing-taste/Manufacturing Tastethewalrus.caCheddar exports totaledconvert234000000lbsonin 1904, but by 2012, Canada was a net importer of cheese.James L. Kraftgrew up on a dairy farm in Ontario, before moving to Chicago. According to the writer Sarah Champman, "Although we cannot wholly lay the decline of cheese craft in Canada at the feet of James Lewis Kraft, it did correspond with the rise of Krafts processed cheese empire."Most Canadian Cheddar is produced by a number of large companies in Ontario, though other provinces produce some and some smaller artisanal producers exist. The annual production is 120,000 tons.cite webhttp://www.canadianliving.com/food/__all_you_need_is_cheese/types_of_cheddar_cheese.phpTypes of Cheddar cheese, Canadian LivingCanadianLiving.comIt is aged a minimum of three months, but much of it is held for much longer, up to 10 years.

Canadian Cheddar cheese soup is a featured dish at theCanada (Epcot)Canada pavilionatEpcot, inWalt Disney World ResortWalt Disney World.cite webhttp://allears.net/din/rec_ched.htmRecipe for Canadian Cheddar cheese soup at Epcot
article.heading: New Zealand
article.paragraph: Much of the Cheddar cheese in New Zealand is factory produced, but of good quality. Most of it is sold young within the country. TheAnchor (brand)Anchordairy company ships New Zealand Cheddars to the UK, where they mature for another year or so.

article.paragraph: Double imagerightPDO-Logo.svg120WestcountryCheddar-Counties.svg120PDO logo can be displayed on any approved West Country Farmhouse Cheddar cheeseThe four English counties in the PDOOnly one producer of the cheese is now based inCheddar, SomersetCheddaritself, the Cheddar Gorge Cheese Co.Cite webhttp://www.cheddargorgecheeseco.co.ukCheddar Gorge Cheese CompanyThe name "cheddar" is not protected by the European Union, though the name "West Country Farmhouse Cheddar" has an EUProtected Geographical Statusprotected designation of origin, and may only be produced inSomerset,Devon,DorsetandCornwall, using milk sourced from those counties.Cite webhttp://www.defra.gov.uk/foodrin/industry/regional/foodname/products/registered/westcoun.htm[[Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs]]EU Protected Food Names Scheme – UK registered names22 July 2009Cheddar is usually sold as mild, medium, mature, extra mature or vintage. Mature cheddar is the best-selling variety in the UK.cite newsHaleBethMature-cheddar-cheese-sales-soar-curry-loving-Britain-gets-taste-stronger-foodhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1218093/Mature-cheddar-cheese-sales-soar-curry-loving-Britain-gets-taste-stronger-food.htmlThe Daily MailLondonCheddar produced inOrkneyis registered as an EUprotected geographical indicationunder the name "Orkney Scottish Island Cheddar".cite webentering a name in the register of protected designations of origin and protected geographical indications (Orkney Scottish Island Cheddar (PGI))http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uriOfficial Journal of the European Union19 March 2014
article.heading: United States
article.paragraph: File:Bravo Cheddar.jpgleft200pxthumbCheddar-style cheese from Bravo Farms,Traver, CaliforniaThe state ofWisconsinproduces the most Cheddar cheese in the US; other centers of production include:California,Idaho,upstate New York,Vermont,Oregon,Texas, andOklahoma. It is sold in several varieties (mild, medium, sharp, extra-sharp, New York-style, white-, and Vermont). New York-style Cheddar is particularly "sharp"/acidic, but tends to be somewhat softer than the milder-tasting varieties. Cheddar that does not contain annatto is frequently labelled "white Cheddar" or "Vermont Cheddar" (regardless of whether it was actually produced there). Vermont's three creameries produce what is regarded as first-class Cheddar cheeses: theCabot Creamery, which produces the 16-month-old "Private Stock Cheddar", the Grafton Village Company, and Shelburne Farms.Ridgway, Judy.The Cheese Companion. Running Press, 2004, p. 77.

Some cheeses called "Cheddar" are actually flavouredprocessed cheesesor "cheese foods"; they often bear little resemblance to their natural namesakes. Examples includeEasy Cheese: a cheese-food packaged in a pressurized spray can; also, as packs of square, sliced, individually wrapped, "processed cheese" (sometimes also pasteurised).

Cheddar is one of several products used by theUnited States Department of Agricultureto track the status of America's overalldairy industry; reports are issued weekly detailing prices and production quantities.
article.heading: Record cheddars
article.paragraph: U.S.PresidentAndrew Jacksononce held an open house party at theWhite Houseat which he served a 1,400-lb (640-kg) block of Cheddar cheese.Cite webhttp://clinton3.nara.gov/WH/glimpse/presidents/html/aj7.htmlThe White HouseThe Presidents of the United States of AmericaAndrew Jackson24 October 2008

A cheese ofconvert7000lbkgonwas produced inIngersoll, Ontario, in 1866 and exhibited in New York and Britain; it was immortalised in thepoem"Ode on the Mammoth Cheese Weighing over 7,000 Pounds"Wikisource:Ode on the Mammoth Cheese Weighing over 7,000 PoundsbyJames McIntyre (poet)James McIntyre, a Canadian poet.cite webhttp://rpo.library.utoronto.ca/poets/mcintyre-jamesMcIntyre, JamesUniversity of Toronto Libraries15 January 2013

In 1893, farmers from the town ofPerth, Ontario, produced "The Mammoth Cheese", which weighedconvert22000lbkgonfor theWorld's Columbian ExpositionChicago World's Fair. It was planned to be exhibited at the Canadian display, but the mammoth cheese fell through the floor and was placed on a reinforced concrete floor in the Agricultural Building. It received the most journalistic attention at the fair and was awarded the bronze medal.cite webMcNicholSusanThe Story of the Mammoth Cheesehttp://www.urbanmarket.com/all-about-perth/mammoth.htmlArchives of the Perth Museum15 January 2013A larger, Wisconsin cheese ofconvert34951lbkgonwas made for the1964 New York World's Fair. A cheese this size would use the equivalent of the daily milk production of 16,000cattlecows.cite webMullins Wisconsin Cheesehttp://www.mullinscheese.com/index.php?optionMullins Cheese15 January 2013

Oregon members of theFederation of American Cheese-makerscreated the largest Cheddar cheese in 1989. The cheese weighedconvert56850lbkgon.cite webCheddar Cheese and Cider Farmshttp://www.gorges-to-visit.com/CheddarGorge-CheddarCheeseandCiderFarms.htmlGorges to visit15 January 2013
